content:
Summary

With a small group, I assisted with the production of a 3D animated short film. Working with Autodesk Maya, we crafted everything from scratch to make a comical and memorable animation.

Process

Our animated short began with a series of simple sketches as we finalized our narrative. After, we collaborated together to model, texture, light, and animate our scene. After rendering each frame, we put on the final touches before presenting it to the class. Every model had to me made from scratch, and we put our knowledge of modeling and rigging to the test.

Result

The Sandwich was screened in front of the class and received an A. It was applauded for it's use of lighting, animation, and character rigging.
title: The Sandwich
subtitle: 3D Animated Short

images.title: A hand appears!
images.caption: A mysterious metal hand grabs the lettuce! The tomato and bologni seem amused, oblivious to their impending fate...

images.caption: For one of the earlier assignments, we had to model, texture, and light a small scene. I chose to create a kitchen counter, with a blender, toaster, knife, cutting board, and an orange to top it off.

title: UFOria
subtitle: Immersive 3D Game World
content:
Summary

Using the 3D development platform Unity, my group set out to create an interactive immersive experience. Our unique world let players explore a UFO abduction using Wii motion controls.

Process

After brainstorming our idea, we began by sketching out our framework. Once we were satisfied, we began modelling and gathering assets for our project. As we were constructing our game world, we did multiple user tests to make sure the experience was fun and bug-free.

Result

Our project was featured in a class showcase at SFU's Surrey Campus and received a mark of 24/25.!!!

images.title: Barn Model
images.caption: A model of a barn used as an in-game asset. Modeled and textures by myself.

images.title: Starting Area
images.caption: At the start of the game, you are in a house, but you notice some strange noises outside, your objective is to grab a flashlight and investigate.

images.title: UFO Outside
images.caption: You venture outside, but shortly after setting foot on your farmland, you see a UFO fly overhead!

images.title: Inside the UFO
images.caption: After you a brought inside the UFO, you come across a secret chamber used for alien experiments.

images.title: UFO Exploding
images.caption: After activating the self-destruct button, you pilot a small ship in order to escape the exploding UFO.

title: Scrollbinder
subtitle: AngularJS Project
content:
Summary

ScrollBinder is a character planner app for the popular table-top game, Dungeons and Dragons. Created as part of a mobile design course, we were given the task of creating a web app that also utilized web services. ScrollBinder uses Google's Realtime API to enable collaboration between players.

Process

Initially, I had to decide which framwork to use. I settled upon Angular JS, and decided to make an app which followed Google's Material Design Specs. The first phase of development consisted of creating a working app that could track player stats and traits. The second phase included adding Google's Realtime API to allow groups of players to keep track of important adventure details.

Result

ScrollBinder successfully reimagined the DnD experience by bringing. The responsive design allows it to work on any device, which greatly improves accessibility. I shared this app with my personal DnD group, and they continue to give me positive reviews and constructive feedback.

Summary

DiceRoller was a small web app prototype I worked on for my mobile design class. The goal was to take an app idea and create something completely unique and experimental. I decided to create an app that allowed users to roll 3D dice using unique gestures and movements. It requires a mobile phone with multi-touch or an accelerometer to use.

Process

We were given two weeks to reinvent an app with unique gestures. I decided to use threeJS and, physiJS libraries, which allowed me to create 3D objects complete with physics. My source of inspiration was the dice effect from the classic board game Trouble.

Result

This assignment was a true test of my JavaScript skills. After two weeks I had a working prototype that was able to use two different kinds of dice (d4 and d6). The dice can be rolled via a pinch gesture, or by moving the device up and down.
subtitle: ThreeJS Mobile Web App
title: Diceroller
Harvey The Hamster
subtitle: Video Project
content:
Summary

This individual assignment challenged my abilities as a media artist. Using the song Harvey the Wonder Hamster by Weird Al Yankovic as the base concept, I brainstormed, storyboarded, and edited until I was happy with the final outcome.

Process

This assignment began with brainstorming and storyboarding the rough concept. This concept was submitted for feedback, which I included in the final video. I had to book rooms, rent equiment/instruments, and edit the film. Once I had all my footage, I used Primiere Pro and Adobe After Effects to add a funky visualizer effect and key out the green screen.

Result

When it was finished, Harvey The Wonder Hamster was shown to the class and received a mark of 23/25.

title: Kinect Remote
subtitle: Gesture Control App
content:
Summary

For this project, we were put into teams of two. Our goal was to take an existing electronic device and minimize it to the extreme. We chose a video remote, and we decided to replace the complex controller with simple hand gestures.

Process

We began by drawing out our ideas and then picking the ones we felt most confident with. We thought about using colour tracking, but we decided that the Kinect was the best way to achieve our desired functionality.

Result

The video remote was featured in a class showcase where students and faculty could try it themselves. Our project received an A grade.

images.title: Hand Tracking 1
images.caption: Test footage shows us using Processing and the Kintect SDK to do hand tracking. The user controls the volume by gesturing up or down.

images.title: Hand Tracking 2
images.caption: Test footage shows us using Processing and the Kintect SDK to do hand tracking. The user controls the volume by gesturing up or down.

images.title: Hand Tracking 3
images.caption: Here's how the previous images looked from a different perspective. The Kintect is next to the laptop so we can quickly test our setup.

images.title: Two hands at once
images.caption: More test footage, this time we were able to track both left and right hands seperately.

images.title: Working demo
images.caption: For our working demo, we use a short scene from the movie 'Hot Fuzz'. The user can play or pause the movie by gesturing left or right, and control the volume with up or down.
